item.title: Chris add a quote by Herman Melville
item.description: "for there is no folly of the beast of the earth which is not infinitely outdone by the madness of men " -- Herman Melville

item.title: Chris add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "Thus violent deeds live after men upon the earth, and traces of war and bloodshed will survive in mournful shapes long after those who worked the desolation are but atoms of earth themselves." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Chris add a quote by Charles Dickens
item.description: "It is a pleasant world we live in, sir, a very pleasant world. There are bad people in it, Mr. Richard, but if there were no bad people, there would be no good lawyers." -- Charles Dickens

item.title: Chris add a quote by Sinclair Lewis
item.description: "What are these unheard of sins you condemn so much - and like so well?" -- Sinclair Lewis

item.title: Chris add a quote by S치ndor M치rai
item.description: "But like every kiss, this one is an answer, a clumsy but tender answer to a question that eludes the power of language." -- S치ndor M치rai

item.title: Chris add a quote by G.K. Chesterton
item.description: "Suppose, my dear Chadd, suppose it is we who are the idiots because we are not afraid of devils in the dark?" -- G.K. Chesterton

item.title: Chris add a quote by Nikolai Gogol
item.description: "Even a stone has its uses, and man who is the most intelligent of all creatures must be of some use, hasn't he?" -- Nikolai Gogol

item.title: Chris add a quote by Nikolai Gogol
item.description: "How many crooked, out-of-the-way, narrow, impassable, and devious paths has humanity chosen in the attempt to attain eternal truth, while before it the straight road lay open...It is wider and more open and resplendent than all other paths, lying as it does in the full glare of the sun, and lit up by many lights in the night, but men have streamed past it in blind darkness. And how many times...have they still managed to swerve away from it and go astray, have managed in the broad light of day to get into the impassable out-of-the-way places again, have managed again to throw a blinding mist over each other's eyes, and running after will-o'-the-wisps have managed to reach the brink of the precipice only to ask themselves with horror: 'Where is the way out? Where is the road?' The present generation sees everything clearly, it is amazed and laughs at the folly of its ancestors...and self-confidently enters on a fresh set of errors at which their descendants will laugh again later on." -- Nikolai Gogol
